description: 1570, of imitative origin; Compare also Saterland Frisian Kloang, West Frisian klank, Dutch klank, German Klang (from klingen), Danish and Swedish klang, Latin clangere.

entries.meaning: A loud, ringing sound, like that made by free-hanging metal objects striking each other.
The cry of some birds, including the crane and the goose.
(psychology, psychiatry) A word or phrase linked only by sound and not by meaning, characteristic of some mental disorders.
examples: For much of this day, Mrs Y. wrote in her diary, covering page after page in a rapid scrawl full of paligraphic repetitions, puns, clangs, and violent, perseverative crossings-out  [â€¦]

verbs.description: clang (third-person singular simple present clangs, present participle clanging, simple past and past participle clanged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strike (objects) together so as to produce a clang.
(intransitive) To give out a clang; to resound.
